item.title: 5-Go框架
item.description: <h1 id="goweb框架--gin">GoWeb框架--Gin</h1>

item.title: 5-Gin-快速开始
3-Go指南-泛型
4-Go指南-并发
2-Go指南-方法和接口
1-Go指南
实用小工具
PostgreSQL中筛选月份和年份查询数据集
item.description: <figure class="highlight sql"><table><tr><td class="gutter"><pre><span class="line">1</span><br><span class="line">2</span><br><span class="line">3</span><br><span class="line">4</span><br></pre></td><td class="code"><pre><span class="line"><span class="comment">-- 日期查询 PostgreSQL中筛选月份和年份查询数据集 三种方法</span></span><br><span class="line"><span class="keyword">select</span> <span class="operator">*</span> <span class="keyword">from</span> srm.cux_5_offline_purchase <span class="keyword">where</span> <span class="built_in">extract</span>(<span class="keyword">year</span> <span class="keyword">from</span> op_createdate )<span class="operator">=</span><span class="number">2024</span> <span class="keyword">and</span> <span class="built_in">extract</span>(<span class="keyword">month</span> <span class="keyword">from</span> op_createdate)<span class="operator">=</span><span class="number">2</span>;</span><br><span class="line"><span class="keyword">select</span> <span class="operator">*</span> <span class="keyword">from</span> srm.cux_5_offline_purchase <span class="keyword">where</span> date_part(<span class="string">&#x27;year&#x27;</span>, op_createdate) <span class="operator">=</span> <span class="number">2024</span> <span class="keyword">AND</span> date_part(<span class="string">&#x27;month&#x27;</span>, op_createdate) <span class="operator">=</span> <span class="number">3</span>;</span><br><span class="line"><span class="comment">-- SELECT * FROM srm.cux_5_offline_purchase WHERE op_createdate &gt;= &#x27;2024-2-01&#x27; AND op_createdate &lt;= &#x27;2024-2-28&#x27;; 不推荐</span></span><br></pre></td></tr></table></figure>

item.title: 正则表达式
修改avue默认组件样式
D3.js V3版本 学习笔记
03-Mybatis-Plus @SqlParser注解
02-String、Date、LocalDate之间的转换
Hexo中支持Latex公式
Exercise 2
item.description:
<h1 id="exercise-2">Exercise 2</h1> <h4 id="section">2.1</h4> <p> Let <span class="math inline">\(f(x)=(x-a_1)(x-a_2)(x-a_3)\)</span> be a monic cubic polynomial with roots <span class="math inline">\(a_1, a_2, a_3\)</span>, then the constant term of <span class="math inline">\(f\)</span> is <span class="math inline">\(-a_1a_2a_3\)</span>.</p> <p> Let <span class="math inline">\(E\)</span> be an elliptic curve defined by <span class="math inline">\(y^2=x^3+Ax+B\)</span>. Let <span class="math inline">\(P_1=(x_1,y_1)\)</span> and <span class="math inline">\(P_2=(x_2,y_2)\)</span> be points on <span class="math inline">\(E\)</span> with <span class="math inline">\(P_1,P_2
eq \infty\)</span> and define <span class="math inline">\(P_1+P_2=P_3=(x_3,y_3)\)</span>. Define a polynomial <span class="math inline">\(F(x,y)=x^3+Ax+B-y^2=0\)</span> based on the equation of <span class="math inline">\(E\)</span>. Let the line through <span class="math inline">\(P_1\)</span> and <span class="math inline">\(P_2\)</span> is <span class="math inline">\(y=l(x)=m(x-x_1)+y_1\)</span>, where <span class="math inline">\(m=(y_2-y_1)/(x_2-x_1)\)</span>. Then we have <span class="math display">\[ F(x,y)=F\left(x,l(x)ight)=x^3+Ax+B-(mx+y_1-mx_1)^2=(x-x_1)(x-x_2)(x-x_3). \]</span> Thus, <span class="math display">\[x_3= rac{(x_1y_2-x_2y_1)^2-B(x_1-x_2)^2}{x_1x_2(x_1-x_2)^2},\quad y_3=m(x_1-x_3)-y_1.\]</span></p> <p>​</p> <p> Direct calculations can prove that <span class="math inline">\(x_3=m^2-x_1-x_2\)</span>.</p> <h4 id="section-1">2.2</h4> <p>Let <span class="math inline">\(P_1=(3,5)\)</span>, then <span class="math inline">\(2P_1=\left(129/100,-383/1000ight)\)</span>.</p> <h4 id="section-2">2.3</h4> <p> <span class="math inline">\(P+Q=(-4,-3) 	ext{ and } (P+Q)+R=(72,611).\)</span></p> <p> <span class="math inline">\(Q+R=(218/49, -4353/343) 	ext{ and } P+(Q+R)=(72,611).\)</span> We have <span class="math inline">\((P+Q)+R=P+(Q+R).\)</span></p> <h4 id="section-3">2.4</h4> <p> <span class="math inline">\(P+Q=(-6,5).\)</span></p> <p> We can calculate that <span class="math inline">\(2P=(929/16,28175/64),\)</span> then <span class="math inline">\(2P\)</span> on <span class="math inline">\(E\)</span> mod 5 is <span class="math inline">\((4,0).\)</span> Similarly, we have <span class="math inline">\(P+Q=(-6,5),\)</span> then <span class="math inline">\(P+Q\)</span> on <span class="math inline">\(E\)</span> mod 5 is also <span class="math inline">\((4,0).\)</span></p> <h4 id="section-4">2.5</h4> <p>The point <span class="math inline">\((x,0)\)</span> is nonsingular if and only if <span class="math inline">\(\partial f/\partial x=3x^2+A
eq 0.\)</span></p> <h4 id="section-5">2.6</h4> <p><span class="math inline">\(P+Q+R=\infty \Longleftrightarrow P+Q=-R \Longleftrightarrow P, Q, R\)</span> are collinear.</p> <h4 id="section-6">2.7</h4> <p>The point <span class="math inline">\((0,c)\)</span> is the identity for the group law on <span class="math inline">\(C\)</span>, the addition law is <span class="math display">\[ (u_1,v_1)+(u_2,v_2)=\left( rac{u_1v_2+u_2v_1}{c(1+du_1u_2v_1v_2)}, rac{v_1v_2-u_1u_2}{c(1-du_1u_2v_1v_2)}ight). \]</span> Since <span class="math inline">\((c,0)+(c,0)=(0,-c)\)</span> and <span class="math inline">\((0,-c)+(0,-c)=(0,c)\)</span>, 4 is the smallest positive integer such that <span class="math inline">\(n(c,0)=\infty\)</span>, thus the point <span class="math inline">\((c,0)\)</span> has order 4.</p> <h4 id="section-7">2.8</h4> Let <span class="math inline">\(k=k_0+2k_1+4k_2+\cdots+2^{n}a_{n}\)</span> with <span class="math inline">\(k_i\in\{0,1\}(i=0,1,\cdots,n).\)</span>\ When <span class="math inline">\(n=0\)</span>,that is <span class="math inline">\(k=k_0\)</span>, it is obvious. Suppose the conclusion holds for <span class="math inline">\(n={\ell-1}\)</span>, let's show that the conclusion is also true for <span class="math inline">\(n=\ell\)</span>. <p>We are done.</p> <h4 id="section-8">2.9</h4> <p><span class="math inline">\(E\)</span> is an elliptic curve defined by <span class="math inline">\(y^2+a_1xy+a_3y=x^3+a_2x^2+a_4x+a_6\)</span>, the vertical line through <span class="math inline">\(P=(x_0,y_0)\)</span> is <span class="math inline">\(x=x_0\)</span>. The line and curve intersect at <span class="math inline">\(P=(x_0,y_0)\)</span> and <span class="math inline">\(-P=(x_0,y_1)\)</span>, substituting <span class="math inline">\(x=x_0\)</span> into the equation of elliptic curve. We have <span class="math inline">\(y_0+y_1=-a_1x_0-a_3\)</span>, thus <span class="math inline">\(-P=(x_0,-a_1x_0-a_3-y_0)\)</span>.</p> <h4 id="section-9">2.10</h4> <p>It is obvious that <span class="math inline">\((x,y,z), (-x,-y,-z)\in \mathbf{R}^3\)</span> map into <span class="math inline">\((x:y:z)\in \mathbf{P^2_R}\)</span>.</p> <h4 id="section-10">2.11</h4> <p> If the line <span class="math inline">\(a_1x+b_1y+c_1z=0\)</span> is parallel with the line <span class="math inline">\(a_2x+b_2y+c_2z=0\)</span>, then they intersect at point <span class="math inline">\((b_1:-a_1:0)=(b_2:-a_2:0)\)</span>. Otherwise, they intersect at point <span class="math inline">\((b_2c_1-b_1c_2:a_1c_2-a_2c_1:a_2b_1-a_1b_2)\)</span>.</p> <p> Let <span class="math inline">\(P_1, P_2\)</span> be two distinct points on <span class="math inline">\(P(K)\)</span> and <span class="math inline">\(u,v\)</span> be representative vectors. Then <span class="math inline">\(u,v\)</span> are linearly independent for otherwise <span class="math inline">\(u=\lambda v\)</span> and <span class="math inline">\(P_1=P_2\)</span>.\ Let <span class="math inline">\(U\in K\)</span> be the 2-dimensional vector space spanned by <span class="math inline">\(u\)</span> and <span class="math inline">\(v\)</span>, then <span class="math inline">\(P(U)\in P(K)\)</span> is a line containing <span class="math inline">\(P_1\)</span> and <span class="math inline">\(P_2\)</span>.\ Suppose <span class="math inline">\(P(U^{\prime})\)</span> is another such line containing <span class="math inline">\(P_1\)</span> and <span class="math inline">\(P_2\)</span>, then <span class="math inline">\(u,v\in U^{\prime}\)</span> and so the space spanned by <span class="math inline">\(u,v\)</span> (namely <span class="math inline">\(U\)</span>) is the subspace of <span class="math inline">\(U^{\prime}\)</span>. But <span class="math inline">\(U\)</span> and <span class="math inline">\(U^{\prime}\)</span> are 2-dimensional so <span class="math inline">\(U=U^{\prime}\)</span> and the line is thus unique.</p> <h4 id="section-11">2.12</h4> <p>Since <span class="math inline">\((a,b,c)M=(a,b,c) \left(  egin{array}{c c} a_1 &amp; b_1\ a_2 &amp; b_2\ a_3 &amp; b_3 \end{array} ight)=\left(aa_1+ba_2+ca_3,ab_1+bb_2+cb_3ight)=(0,0)\)</span>, then <span class="math inline">\(ax+by+cz=a(a_1u+b_1v)+b(a_2u+b_2v)+c(a_3u+b_3v)=(aa_1+ba_2+ca_3)u+(ab_1+bb_2+cb_3)v=0\)</span>.</p> <h4 id="section-12">2.13</h4> <p> Legendre equation is <span class="math inline">\(y^2=x(x-1)(x-\lambda)=y^2=x^3-(\lambda+1)x^2+\lambda x\)</span>, where <span class="math display">\[  egin{aligned} b_2&amp;=a^2_1+4a_2=-4(\lambda+1),\ b_4&amp;=2a_4+a_1a_3=2\lambda,\ b_6&amp;=a^2_3+4a_6=0,\ b_8&amp;=a^2_1a_6+4a_2a_6-a_1a_3a_4+a_2a^2_3-a^2_4=-\lambda^2,\ c_4&amp;=b^2_2-24b_4=16(\lambda+1)^2-48\lambda=2^4(\lambda^2-\lambda+1),\ \Delta&amp;=-b^2_2b_8-8b^3_4-27b^2_6+9b_2b_4b_6=2^4\lambda^2(\lambda+1)^2-2^6\lambda^3=2^4\lambda^2(\lambda-1)^2. \end{aligned} \]</span> Thus, the <span class="math inline">\(j\)</span>-invariant is <span class="math display">\[ j= rac{c^3_4}{\Delta}=2^8 rac{(\lambda^2-\lambda+1)^3}{\lambda^2(\lambda-1)^2}. \]</span></p> <p> Directly calculate.</p> <p> Calculated directly from (a).</p> <h4 id="section-13">2.14</h4> <p> Let <span class="math inline">\(u=1+t, v=mt\)</span> for some <span class="math inline">\(m\)</span>, then <span class="math inline">\(u^2-v^2=(1+t)^2-(mt)^2=(1-m^2)t^2+2t=0\)</span>. Discarding the solution <span class="math inline">\(t=0\)</span>, we obtain <span class="math inline">\(t=2/(m^2-1)\)</span>, hence <span class="math display">\[ u=1+t= rac{m^2+1}{m^2-1},\quad v=mt= rac{2m}{m^2-1}. \]</span></p> <p> Let <span class="math inline">\(w=0\)</span>, then <span class="math inline">\(u^2-v^2=w^2=0\)</span>, hence <span class="math inline">\(u=\pm v\)</span>. Thus, the projective curve has two point at infinity, <span class="math inline">\((1:1:0)\)</span> and <span class="math inline">\((1:-1:0)\)</span>.</p> <p> Since the parameterization obtained in (a) can be written in projective coordinates as <span class="math inline">\((u:v:w)=(m^2+1:2m:m^2-1)\)</span>, then the values <span class="math inline">\(m=\pm 1\)</span> correspond to points <span class="math inline">\((1:\pm 1:0)\)</span>, that is, correspond to the points at infinity. In the graph, we can find that <span class="math inline">\(u=\pm v\)</span> is asymptote to hyperbola <span class="math inline">\(u^2-v^2=1\)</span>, they intersect at infinity.</p> <h4 id="section-14">2.15</h4> <p> Let <span class="math inline">\(L\)</span> be the line through <span class="math inline">\((u_0,0,0)\)</span> with slope <span class="math inline">\(m\)</span>: <span class="math display">\[ u=u_0+t,\qquad v=mt. \]</span> This yields <span class="math inline">\(a(u_0+t)^2+bm^2t^2=e\)</span>, which yields <span class="math inline">\((a+bm^2)t^2+2au_0t=0\)</span>. Discarding the solution <span class="math inline">\(t=0\)</span>, we obtain <span class="math inline">\(t=-2au_0/(a+bm^2)\)</span>. Substitute the expression just obtained for <span class="math inline">\(u\)</span> to obtain <span class="math display">\[ dw^2=f-( rac{bu_0m^2-au_0}{a+bm^2})^2. \]</span> This may be rewritten as <span class="math display">\[  egin{aligned} (a+bm^2)^2w^2&amp;= rac{(a+bm^2)^2}{d}f- rac{c(au_0-bu_0m^2)^2}{d}\ &amp;=( rac{b^2f}{d}- rac{b^2u_0^2c}{d})m^4+\cdots \end{aligned} \]</span> Let <span class="math inline">\(r=(a+bm^2)w\)</span>, then we obtain <span class="math inline">\(r^2=2ab(f+u_0^2c)/d m^2+k_2m+k_3\)</span> for some <span class="math inline">\(k_2,k_3\)</span>, which has the form "square=degree2 polynomial in <span class="math inline">\(m\)</span>".</p> <p> The Jacobian matrix <span class="math inline">\(\left(  egin{array}{c c c} F_u &amp; F_v &amp; F_w\ G_u &amp; G_v &amp; G_w \end{array} ight)_{(u_0,0,0)}= \left(  egin{array}{c c c} 2au_0 &amp; 0 &amp; 0\ 2cu_0 &amp; 0 &amp; 0 \end{array} ight)\)</span>, hence the Jacobian matrix at <span class="math inline">\((u_0,0,0)\)</span> has rank 1. Since the rank is less than 2, this means that the point is a singular point.</p> <h4 id="section-15">2.16</h4> <p>Let <span class="math display">\[ x_1= rac{12d}{x+y}\qquad	ext{and}\qquad y_1=36d rac{x-y}{x+y}. \]</span></p> <h4 id="section-16">2.17</h4> <p> <span class="math inline">\(\alpha(P_1+P_2)=-(P_1+P_2)=(-P_1)+(-P_2)=\alpha(P_1)+\alpha(P_2).\)</span></p> <p> The map is clearly bijective and homomorphic by direct calculation.\ We can also show that the map is a isogeny, then it is homorphic.</p> <p> It is similar as (b).</p> <h4 id="section-17">2.18</h4> <p> If <span class="math inline">\(a_2=a_4=0\)</span>, then the equation of elliptic curve is <span class="math inline">\(f=y^2-x^3-a_6=0\)</span>. We obtain <span class="math inline">\(\partial f/\partial y=2y, \partial f/\partial x=-3x^2\)</span> and <span class="math inline">\(\partial f/\partial y, \partial f/\partial x\)</span> vanish at <span class="math inline">\(P\in E[2]\)</span>, which is not allowed.</p> <p> The change of variables <span class="math inline">\(x=x_1+(a_4/a_2)\)</span> yields the equation <span class="math display">\[y_1^2=\left(x_1+ rac{a_4}{a_2}ight)^3+a_2\left(x_1+ rac{a_4}{a_2}ight)^2+a_4\left(x_1+ rac{a_4}{a_2}ight)+a_6.\]</span> The coefficient of <span class="math inline">\(x\)</span> is <span class="math inline">\(3a^2_4/a^2_2+3a_4=0\)</span>, hence the equation has the form <span class="math inline">\(y^2_1=x^3_1+a_2^{\prime}x^2_1+a_6^{\prime}\)</span>.</p> <p> The <span class="math inline">\(j\)</span>-invariant of elliptic curve <span class="math inline">\(y^2=x^3+a_2x^2+a_6\)</span> is <span class="math display">\[ j=- rac{a^3_2}{a_6}. \]</span> If <span class="math inline">\(-a^3_2/a_6=-(a^{\prime}_2)^3/a^{\prime}_6\)</span>, then <span class="math inline">\((a^{\prime}_2)^3/a^3_2=a^{\prime}_6/a_6\)</span>, hence there exists <span class="math inline">\(\mu\in  ar{K}^*\)</span> such that <span class="math inline">\(a_2^{\prime}=\mu^2a_2\)</span> and <span class="math inline">\(a_6^{\prime}=\mu^6a_6\)</span>.</p> <p> </p> <p> If <span class="math inline">\(j=0\)</span>, we use the curve <span class="math inline">\(E:y^2=x^3+x\)</span>. Otherwise, we consider the curve <span class="math display">\[ y^2+xy=x^3- rac{1}{j_0}. \]</span></p> <p> Let elliptic curve <span class="math inline">\(E\)</span> and <span class="math inline">\(E^{\prime}\)</span> have the same <span class="math inline">\(j-\)</span> invariant. Consider the following two cases:</p> <p>Case I. <span class="math inline">\(j(E)
eq0\)</span>. In this case <span class="math inline">\(E\)</span> and <span class="math inline">\(E^{\prime}\)</span> have Weierstrass equations of the form <span class="math display">\[ y^2=x^3+a_2x^2+a_6. \]</span> The only substitutions preserving this type of equation are <span class="math display">\[ x=u^2x^\prime \qquad 	ext{and} \qquad y=u^3y^{\prime}. \]</span></p> <p>Case II. <span class="math inline">\(j(E)=0\)</span>. In this case <span class="math inline">\(E\)</span> and <span class="math inline">\(E^{\prime}\)</span> have Weierstrass equations of the form <span class="math display">\[ y^2=x^3+a_4x+a_6. \]</span> The substitutions preserving this form look like <span class="math display">\[ x=u^2x^{\prime}+r \qquad 	ext{and} \qquad y=u^3y^{\prime}. \]</span> An isomorphism from <span class="math inline">\(E\)</span> to <span class="math inline">\(E^{\prime}\)</span> is obtained by choosing <span class="math inline">\(u\)</span> and <span class="math inline">\(r\)</span> to satisfy <span class="math display">\[ u^4=a_4^{\prime} \qquad 	ext{and} \qquad r^3+a_4r+a_6-u^6a_6^{\prime}=0. \]</span></p> <h4 id="section-18">2.19</h4> <p> Since <span class="math inline">\((x,y)\)</span> and <span class="math inline">\(\alpha(x,y)\)</span> lie on <span class="math inline">\(E\)</span>, then <span class="math display">\[  rac{(x^3+Ax+B)s(x)^2}{t(x)^2}= rac{p(x)^3+Ap(x)q(x)^2+Bq(x)^3}{q(x)^3}. \]</span> Let <span class="math inline">\(u(x)=p(x)^3+Ap(x)q(x)^2+Bq(x)^3\)</span>, if <span class="math inline">\(q\)</span> and <span class="math inline">\(u\)</span> have common root, then <span class="math inline">\(p\)</span> and <span class="math inline">\(q\)</span> have common root, which is not allowed.</p> <p> From (a), we obtain <span class="math display">\[ (x^3+Ax+B)s(x)^2q(x)^3=u(x)t(x)^2. \]</span> Since <span class="math inline">\(t(x_0)=0\)</span>, so the multiplicity of <span class="math inline">\(x_0\)</span> over <span class="math inline">\(u(x)t(x)^2\)</span> at least 2. Notice that <span class="math inline">\(x^3+Ax+B\)</span> has no multiple roots and <span class="math inline">\(s(x_0)
eq 0\)</span>, hence <span class="math inline">\(x_0\)</span> is a root of <span class="math inline">\(q(x)\)</span>, that is <span class="math inline">\(q(x_0)=0\)</span>.</p> <h4 id="section-19">2.20</h4> <p>Let <span class="math inline">\(f(x,y)=x^3+ax^2-y^2=0\)</span> describe a curve <span class="math inline">\(C\)</span> in the affine plane and let <span class="math display">\[ x=t,\qquad y=mt \]</span> be a line <span class="math inline">\(L\)</span> written in terms of the parameter <span class="math inline">\(t\)</span>. Let <span class="math inline">\(	ilde{f}(t)=f(t,mt)=t^3+(a-m^2)t^2\)</span> and <span class="math inline">\(t=0\)</span> correspond to point <span class="math inline">\((0,0)\)</span>, thus 2 is the highest power of <span class="math inline">\(t\)</span> that divides <span class="math inline">\(	ilde{f}(t)\)</span>, hence <span class="math inline">\(L\)</span> always intersects the curve to order at least 2. If the order is 3, then <span class="math inline">\(t^3\mid t^3+(a-m^2)t^2\)</span>, that is exactly when <span class="math inline">\(a=m^2\)</span>.</p> <h4 id="section-20">2.21</h4> <p> Let the line through the point <span class="math inline">\((-1,0)\)</span> with slope <span class="math inline">\(m\)</span>: <span class="math inline">\(u=-1+m, v=tm\)</span>. Substitute the equations into circle equation, this yields <span class="math inline">\((t^2+1)m^2-2m=0\)</span>. Discarding the solution <span class="math inline">\(m=0\)</span>, then we obtain <span class="math inline">\(m=2/(t^2+1)\)</span>. Thus, <span class="math display">\[ u=-1+ rac{2}{t^2+1}= rac{t^2-1}{t^2+1},\qquad v= rac{2t}{1+t^2}. \]</span></p> <p> Let <span class="math inline">\(t=m/n\)</span> in the expression of <span class="math inline">\(u\)</span> and <span class="math inline">\(v\)</span> by the parameter <span class="math inline">\(t\)</span>, then <span class="math display">\[ u= rac{t^2-1}{t^2+1}= rac{m^2-n^2}{m^2+n^2},\qquad v= rac{2mn}{m^2+n^2}. \]</span> Let <span class="math inline">\(u=y/z\)</span> and <span class="math inline">\(v=x/z\)</span>, thus there are integers <span class="math inline">\(m,n\)</span> such that <span class="math display">\[ x=2mn,\qquad y=m^2-n^2,\qquad z=m^2+n^2. \]</span> If <span class="math inline">\(\gcd(m,n)=k
eq 1\)</span>, then <span class="math inline">\(k^2\mid \gcd(x,y,z)
eq1\)</span>, which is not allowed, thus <span class="math inline">\(\gcd(m,n)=1\)</span>. If <span class="math inline">\(m\equiv n\pmod 2\)</span>, then there exists integer <span class="math inline">\(q\)</span> such that <span class="math inline">\(m=n+2q\)</span>, this leads to <span class="math inline">\(2\mid \gcd(x,y,z)\)</span>, which is a contradiction, hence <span class="math inline">\(m
ot\equiv n \pmod 2\)</span>.</p> <h4 id="section-21">2.22</h4> <p>Notice that <span class="math display">\[  rac{d}{dx}\left( rac{p(x)}{q(x)}ight)= rac{p^{\prime}(x)q(x)-q^{\prime}(x)p(x)}{q^2(x)}. \]</span> 1. If <span class="math inline">\(p^{\prime}(x)=q^{\prime}(x)=0\)</span>, it is obvious that <span class="math inline">\( rac{d}{dx}\left( rac{p(x)}{q(x)}ight)=0\)</span>.</p> <ol start="2" type="1"> <li>If <span class="math inline">\( rac{d}{dx}\left( rac{p(x)}{q(x)}ight)=0\)</span>, then we obtain <span class="math display">\[  rac{p^{\prime}(x)}{q^\prime(x)}= rac{p(x)}{q(x)}=h(x). \]</span> The equation is equivalent to <span class="math display">\[ p^\prime(x)=h(x)q^\prime(x)\qquad	ext{and}\qquad p(x)=h(x)q(x), \]</span> this yields <span class="math inline">\(h(x)=e^x\)</span>. If <span class="math inline">\(p^\prime(x)
eq 0\)</span>, then <span class="math inline">\(q^\prime(x)
eq 0\)</span>. But <span class="math inline">\(e^xq(x)\)</span> is not a polynomial, it is impossible. Thus <span class="math inline">\(p^\prime(x)=0\)</span>, then <span class="math inline">\(q^\prime(x)=0\)</span>.</li> </ol> <h4 id="section-22">2.23</h4> <p> <span class="math display">\[ j(E^{(d)})=108 rac{(4Ad^2)^3}{4(Ad^2)^3+27(Bd^3)^2}=108 rac{(4A)^3}{4A^3+27B^2}=j(E). \]</span></p> <p> The change of variables <span class="math inline">\(x=dx_1, y=\pm d\sqrt{d}y_1\)</span> transform <span class="math inline">\(E^{(d)}: y^2=x^3+Ad^2x+Bd^3\)</span> into <span class="math inline">\(E: y_1^2=x_1^3+Ax_1+B\)</span>.</p> <p> The change of variables <span class="math inline">\(x=dx_1, y=\pm d^2y_1\)</span> transform <span class="math inline">\(E^{(d)}: y^2=x^3+Ad^2x+Bd^3\)</span> into the form <span class="math inline">\(dy_1^2=x_1^3+Ax_1+B\)</span>.</p> <h4 id="section-23">2.24</h4> <p> Since <span class="math inline">\(\gcd(\alpha, eta)=1\)</span>, so there exist integers <span class="math inline">\(p,q\)</span> such that <span class="math inline">\(p\alpha+q eta=1\)</span>. If cubic polynomial <span class="math inline">\(x(x-\alpha)(x- eta)\)</span> have a triple root, then <span class="math inline">\(p\mid \alpha\)</span> and <span class="math inline">\(p\mid  eta\)</span>. This yields <span class="math inline">\(p\mid p\alpha+q eta=1\)</span>, which is not allowed.</p> <p> Directly calculate.</p> <p> Since <span class="math inline">\( eta \equiv 0\pmod {32}\)</span>, then <span class="math inline">\(\alpha eta/16 \equiv 0 \pmod 2\)</span>. Thus <span class="math inline">\(E_1\)</span> has the form <span class="math inline">\(y_1^2+x_1y_1=x_1^3+ex_1^2\)</span> for some <span class="math inline">\(e\in\mathbf{F}_2\)</span>. This curve is singular at <span class="math inline">\((0,0)\)</span>.</p> <p> Let <span class="math inline">\(	ilde{f}(x_1,\gamma x_1)=x_1^3+(e-\gamma^2-\gamma)x_1^2\)</span> and notice that the line <span class="math inline">\(y_1=\gamma x_1\)</span> intersect <span class="math inline">\(E_1\)</span> at <span class="math inline">\((0,0)\)</span>. It is easy to see that if <span class="math inline">\(\gamma^2+\gamma=e\)</span>, then the line intersects in part (c) to order 3, and if <span class="math inline">\(\gamma^2+\gamma 
eq e\)</span>, then the line intersects in part (c) to order 2.</p> <p> The equation <span class="math inline">\(\gamma^2+\gamma-e=0\)</span> has two solutions <span class="math inline">\(x_1,x_2\)</span> in <span class="math inline">\(\mathbf{\overline{F}}_2\)</span>, if <span class="math inline">\(x_1=x_2\)</span>, then <span class="math inline">\((\gamma-x_1)^2=\gamma^2+\gamma-e\)</span>. But <span class="math display">\[  rac{d}{d\gamma}(\gamma-x_1)^2=0, \qquad  rac{d}{d\gamma}(\gamma^2+\gamma-e)=1
eq 0, \]</span> which is not allowed, hence <span class="math inline">\(x_1
eq x_2\)</span>.</p>

item.title: 数据库
04-国际化操作i18n
实用小工具
